Hi Roberto, we have indeed begun to explore evolving the substrate itself=
.  Our GECCO paper, "Evolving the Placement and Density of Neurons in the H=
yperNEAT Substrate," is an initial step in this direction:

http://eplex.cs=
.ucf.edu/publications/2010/risi.gecco10.html

At present, we are continuing=
 to refine this approach and finding some interesting results.

By the way,=
 others may also be exploring alternative approached to evolving the substr=
ate.  It is a pretty clear next step for the HyperNEAT approach in general.=


ken

e:

> Hi, everybody,

excuse me for my bad English :-)).

> I have a
> question abo=
ut the HyperNEAT algorithm: it seems to me that, for a given node=E2=80=99s=

> substrate with a fixed resolution, the connectivity patterns are evolved=
 by CPPNs,
> but they however keeps a perfect geometrical regularity and ho=
mogeneity inside
> the substrate.
> 
> =C2=A0
> 
> Now, we
> know that huma=
n brain is made up of different parts, each constituted by
> neurons which =
generates different structures with different morphology (so with
> differe=
nt connectivity patterns).
> 
> =C2=A0
> 
> So, my
> question is: can we bu=
ild a variant version of HyperNEAT which can to evolve
> the substrate morp=
hology too, therefore developing, inside it, areas with
> different morphol=
ogical patterns?
> 
> =C2=A0

> lot for your answer.=C2=A0
